componentAttributes.richTextValue: While these are not necessarily projects I have created from scratch, I am a big fan of Udemy courses to expand on or learn new skills - skills which have helped me create some of the projects you do see in my portfolio. The following is a timeline of my curriculum and a promotion of these instructor's content:

Instructor: Mike Wheeler

Completed: August 2018

Review: Helpful resource in passing the Salesforce Admin I certification exam. The content is still probably good and relevant, but the course is now also offered in Lightning Experience as the admin exam question bank evolves and Salesforce Classic is phased out.

Instructor: Mike Wheeler

Completed: December 2018

Review: Helpful resource in passing the Platform App Builder certification exam. The certification itself is a mix of both Admin and Developer. While it was good to understand what content the exam would cover, some of it was a retread of material covered in the above admin course.

Instructor: Deepika Khanna

Completed: January 2019

Review: Helpful resource in passing the Platform Developer I certification exam. The course does a great job of laying out the topics the exam will cover, and then walking through real examples to understand those concepts. However, depending on your own personal experience, a bit more studying may be required in order to feel comfortable taking the exam - memerizing things such as order of execution, govenor limits, etc.

Instructor: Vivek Kapoor

Completed: June 2019

Review: Easy to follow-along course, especially as it was my first exposure to AWS and Node.js. This course provided the basis and concepts I needed to created my own Alexa Skill: Whose Tagline is it Anyway.

Instructor: Andrew Mead

Completed: December 2019

Review: Around this time I started getting really ineterested in JavaScript. Having programmed Lightning Web Components in Salesforce (JavaScript frontend) and a whole Alexa Skill in Node.js - I wanted to dive deeper in the various JavaScript stacks out there and started with this very insightful course.

My follow along code: https://github.com/matthewdoles/nodejs-developer-course

Instructor: Maximilian Schwarzmüller

Completed: January 2020

Review: After finishing the Node.js course I was hooked. With Node.js being the most popular JavaScript backend languages, I wanted to learn one of the most popular frontend languages. Of course you could debate on what is the most popular frontend language, but I landed on this React course largely because it was one of the most popular and recommended on Udemy. Having now completed it, I can see why this comprehensive look into React comes so recommened which covers concepts both new and old. On top of that, I find Maximilian Schwarzmüller to be one of the best instructors on the platform having taken several of his courses as you will see below.

My follow along code: https://github.com/matthewdoles/react-developer-course

Instructor: Maximilian Schwarzmüller

Completed: February 2020

Review: Having finished both a Node.js and React course in quick succession, I wanted to see clearly how the two tied together. While I could have gone at it myself and probably made my way, this course was a great follow-along which provided me the fundamentals of MERN and other similar stacks.

My follow along code: https://github.com/matthewdoles/mern-fullstack-course

Instructor: Maximilian Schwarzmüller

Completed: May 2020

Review: With a good understanding of React, I was turned on to React Native by a friend, Donnie Waters, who has used the stack extensively to develop his own successful mobile app: Rocket League Garage. With this handy course and his guidance, I created my first mobile app: Vigilant - Valorant Strategy.

My follow along code: https://github.com/matthewdoles/react-native-course

Instructor: Brad Traversy

Completed: September 2020

Review: After developing my first mobile app, Vigilant - Valorant Strategy, I receieved alot of interest to port the app to desktop. One of the most intriguing solutions was to port it into an Electron app. Given a mix of lack of time and having been beat to the desktop market by other similar apps, Vigilant has not yet been ported to an Electron app. Though, the course still offers some good material and already conisdering using the framework for future projects.

My follow along code: https://github.com/matthewdoles/electron-course

Instructor: Grohs Fabian

Completed: December 2020

Review: There is really no rhyme or reason for why I took this course other than it sounded cool. At Johnson and Johnson the testing team had started getting into test automation via a Python framework called Robot. Having peeked at some of their scripts, it was cool to see them run test executions and gather their test evidence with a single click of a button. Of course, the initial time of investment to get a project setup with the testing framework is considerable but overall has great long term benefits. This foray into scraping with NodeJs provided me an introduction into the world of automation, especially with the power of Puppeteer. Overall the course was good and provides some good core concepts. However, due to the evolving nature of technology, some of the example sites that he scrapes throughout the course have since changed. For instance, Twitter seemingly used to have a PHP frontend at the time of recording, but now they are using React. Such a change has made most of the content regarding Twitter obsolete.

My follow along code: https://github.com/matthewdoles/node-scrapper-tutorial
